Award.AwardTitle: Optogenetic Dissection of Protein Kinase Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cell responses to external stimuli are controlled by numerous signaling pathways that are themselves interconnected to form signaling networks. Kinases are enzymes that carry out site-specific phosphorylation, the primary form of information transfer in signaling networks. SPARKLE is an approach to controlling the activity of kinases using light; genetically-encoded kinases are engineered to contain a caged lysine residue at their active site, and these enzymes then become active only after exposure to ultraviolet light. By using light to achieve spatial and temporal specificity in the activation of particular kinases, the activity of the cellular sub-networks controlled by these kinases can be dissected. With this approach it will be possible to elucidate cross-talk and feedback mechanisms between signaling pathways, and to define the role of particular pathways in driving the polarization and directed movement of cells.

Broader Impacts: This project will provide interdisciplinary training in chemistry, cell biology, and computational modeling to undergraduate and graduate students. A new laboratory-based course in optogenetics will be developed, and outreach on the role of light in biological systems will be conducted at the Marbles Kids Museum in Raleigh.

This award is supported jointly by the Cellular Dynamics and Function Cluster of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division, and by the Chemistry of Life Processes Program of the Division of Chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The responses of living cells to external stimuli, environmental stressors, and drugs are controlled by biochemical reactions inside the cells that are collectively known as a signal transduction network (STN). Defects in the regulation of the network are the basis for many diseases in humans, including certain cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, immune disorders, and most cancers. The major regulatory enzymes in STNs are kinases, enzymes that transfer phosphate from a donor (usually ATP) to a specific site on another biomolecule, such as a protein or lipid. In this project we developed and applied methods to isolate the effects of specific kinases in cells. The general approach is to introduce a synthetic system in which a non-natural amino acid is incorporated in the ATP-binding site of the kinase. Upon brief exposure to ultraviolet light, the side chain of the non-natural amino acid is converted to that of the natural amino acid, lysine, and ATP binding, as well as enzymatic function, is restored. When combined with activating mutations in the kinase, this system allows only the specific kinase to be activated on demand. The transformative advance exploited in this approach is that our light-activated proteins are genetically encoded; thus, the parallel design and generation of many kinase variants with site-specific caging is feasible. From the standpoint of elucidating STNs, scientific advances include the ability to introduce, for the first time, specific and acute gain-of-function perturbations in a stable cell population, and the ability to pinpoint the influence of each kinase in the STN in an otherwise unstimulated state. Furthermore, using light as an external trigger allows focal stimulation of kinase activity in a particular location in the cell.

We successfully applied this approach to study regulation of, and interactions between, multiple mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathways, which are regarded as master controllers of cell division, differentiation, and programmed cell death. We introduced new light-activated variants of multiple kinases, such as ERK, MKK6, and PAK1, and applied them to the study of STNs. For example, activation of MKK6 was found to negatively regulate ERK and induce programmed cell death, and our approach uniquely and surprisingly revealed that these effects are not (solely) attributable to activation of MKK6’s canonical substrate, p38. In parallel, we were able to isolate the role of PAK1 on regulation of the ERK pathway. Along the way we made several advances in the optogenetic system for introducing these kinases, including the accommodation of different non-natural amino acids and enhancement of expression yields in mammalian cells, as well as development of a light-triggered kinase system in live zebrafish embryos. These new tools are available to the scientific community and will hopefully stimulate research in other laboratories. 

Furthermore, this project contributed to the training of chemistry and chemical engineering graduate students in multiple disciplines, which uniquely combined molecular biology, organic chemistry, fluorescence microscopy, cell biology, and computational biology. These students also mentored several undergraduate students in the lab. At both levels, students from groups underrepresented in Science and Engineering were among those trained. The results of this research and the developed approaches were naturally incorporated into lectures given in courses taught at the University of Pittsburgh and North Carolina State University, as well as the International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) competition, a worldwide synthetic biology competition of undergraduate university students who develop their own projects and conduct summer research to address important societal problems.
